text.p: Israel's Logal Educational and Software Systems Ltd will show a loss of 10 cents a share next year, as revenue growth slows while the company makes the transition to a new sales strategy, Lehman Brothers said.

Analyst Theodor Kundtz said he was lowering his 1997 estimate from break even and widening his forecast fourth-quarter 1996 loss to 14 cents a share from 10 cents. Logal's full-year loss will reach 40 cents a share from his earlier estimate of 34 cents.

He said Logal, a maker of interactive math and science software, would achieve profitability in the second half of 1997. Kundtz said he kept to his full-year 1998 earnings per share estimate of 41 cents and maintained Logal's 1-Buy rating "given long-term potential."
Kundtz said Logal's third-quarter loss exceeded estimates, reaching eight cents a share, (excluding a one-time restructuring charge, versus his estimate of four cents).
He attributed the widening losses to Logal's shift in its direct sales to a narrower list of big customers.
"Given the challenges Logal faces in this transitional period, we are assuming revenues of $12.1 million for the full year (1996), versus our earlier $14.7 million forecast," he said.
